data.title: Clark Haggans death updates — Steelers linebacker & NFL icon dies at 46 as cause unknown & funeral details not announced
data.meta_description: FORMER Steelers linebacker Clark Haggans has died suddenly at the age of 46.TheSuper BowlXL champion spent seven seasons with the Steelers
data.text:
Live Blog

STAR GONE

Clark Haggans death updates — Steelers linebacker & NFL icon dies at 46 as cause unknown & funeral details not announced

FORMER Steelers linebacker Clark Haggans has died suddenly at the age of 46.

The Super Bowl XL champion spent seven seasons with the Steelers, before going on to play for the Arizona Cardinals and the San Francisco 49ers.

Haggans' cause of death has not yet been revealed.

Funeral arrangements for the late NFL star have not been arranged at this time, according to WTAE.

Follow our Clark Haggans death updates blog for news and updates...

Suffered injury in 2008

On March 26, 2008, Haggans agreed to a one-year contract with the Arizona Cardinals.

He was placed on injured reserve with a foot injury on December 19, ending his season.

Three-sport athlete

Haggans attended Palos Verdes Peninsula High School in Southern California where he played football, basketball, and track.

His football team went undefeated in his freshman and sophomore years and he was named all-league at tight end and defensive tackle.

The late NFL star helped lead his varsity team to a league title in 1994.

Haggans' charity work

After retiring in 2013 Haggans would go on to become a prominent supporter of the Black Out Child Abuse Campaign charity.

The campaign serves families and organizations across the country; bringing education, assistance, and support to those in need.

Haggans wore blackout paint as opposed to the stick-on in support of this cause.

Clark Haggans college career

Haggans played for the Colorado State University Rams from 1996 to 1999.

He graduated with a career sack record of 33 and helped lead the Rams to two conference championships.

He was honored with second-team All-WAC honors in 1998 and first-team All-MW honors in 1999.

The late NFL linebacker racked up 12 sacks in 1997 and 1998 and was a key player in the 1997 Holiday Bowl victory over the University of Missouri.

More on Clark Haggans transition to retirement

In a 2019 interview with SteelersNow, the late Haggans described his transition from the NFL to retirement.

He said: "It’s hard when you don’t hear your name called sometimes. That’s why they say the transition can be hard.

"That and it was so regimented everything was on a schedule – especially during football season.

"Everything was consumed by practices, film study, workouts, obligations on and off the field… So adjusting from that is hard."

Clark Haggans dabbled in real estate

In an interview with SteelersNow in 2019 the late linebacker revealed he was involved in real estate post-NFL career.

He said: "I’m just being a dad. Going back and forth between Pittsburgh, Vegas and splitting time with the kids with their mother in Denver.

"I’m also doing some real estate and just being a dad and chilling out."

Accolades throughout entire football career

Clark Haggans achieved success throughout his football career, below are some of his accolades:

First-team All-Mountain West

Colorado State University Athletics Hall of Fame

Super Bowl XL champion

'A true legend'

Fans of late NFL star Clark Haggans continue to pay tribute on social media.

One fan wrote: "So sad to hear about the passing of @CSUFootball legend Clark Haggans.

"He was one of the greatest players in the Sonny Lubick era, but always humble and upbeat. A true legend."

Super Bowl XL statistics

Clark Haggans helped the Pittsburgh Steelers during the team's playoff run in 2005.

The late NFL star had 18 tackles in the playoffs during the championship run.

He added five tackles in the Super Bowl along with his iconic opening drive sack of Seattle’s Matt Hasselbeck.

Clark Haggans’ time on the San Francisco 49ers

On September 2, 2012, Haggans agreed to a one-year contract with the San Francisco 49ers where he only recorded two total tackles in nine games.

Clark Haggans' time on the Arizona Cardinals

On March 26, 2008, Haggans agreed to a one-year contract with the Arizona Cardinals but injured his foot and did not play.

Haggans was re-signed to a three-year contract in 2009 by the Cardinals on March 17.

In his first healthy season with the team in 2009, he registered 74 tackles, 5 sacks, and forced two fumbles in 16 games.

During the 2010 campaign, he racked up 47 tackles, 5 sacks, and 1 forced fumble in 13 games.

Clark Haggans time on the Pittsburgh Steelers

During his stellar Steelers career, Haggans recorded 332 tackles, 12 forced fumbles, and 32.5 sacks.

Haggans spent seven seasons with the Steelers, famously sacking Seattle’s Matt Hasselbeck on the opening drive of the 2005 Super Bowl on the way to victory.

Former NFL QB adds to tributes

Former Cardinals QB Matt Leinart took to Twitter to honor his old teammate.

'Most underrated piece'

Fans are taking to Twitter to praise the late NFL star for being an important piece of the Steelers' defense throughout his time on the team.

The fan wrote: "Damn, man. So sad. RIP to Clark Haggans. Perhaps the most underrated piece of those elite Steelers defenses."

Another fan wrote: "Rest In Peace Clark Haggans!"

Tributes continue to pour in

NFL fans have flooded Twitter to remember the late Steelers linebacker.

One fan wrote: "Clark Haggans' life was obviously so much more than one Super Bowl or the game of football.

"But he was a key piece to some great Steelers' defenses. Nine sacks in 2005, took down Matt Hasselbeck on the opening drive of SB 40.

"Rest in Peace, Clark."

Haggans post-football career

The late NFL star retired in 2013 and would go on to become a prominent supporter of the Black Out Child Abuse Campaign charity.

He was inducted into the Colorado State University Athletics Hall of Fame in 2015.

Haggans' 33 sacks for the Rams still remain a school record.

Haggans early football career

He began his pro football journey as a defensive end at Colorado State University.

Haggans was a teammate of former Steelers teammate Joey Porter and former Cincinnati Bengals linebacker Adrian Ross.

The Steelers drafted Haggans out of the fifth round of the 2000 NFL Draft.

Haggans appeared in the big game three times

Clark Haggans had the opportunity to play in the Super Bowl twice, once with the Pittsburgh Steelers and another with the Arizona Cardinals.

He secured a victory with the Steelers and even famously sacked Seattle’s Matt Hasselbeck on the opening drive of the game.

Unfortunately, when he made it back to the game the second time with the Cardinals in 2008 he lost to his former team.

Haggans appeared once more in 2012 but the 49ers ultimately came up short 34-31 to the Baltimore Ravens.

Career statistics

Haggans recorded 504 total tackles during his 13-year NFL career, tallying 356 solo and 148 assisted.

He continuously harassed quarterbacks as he racked up 46.5 sacks during his time in the league.

The late NFL star forced 16 fumbles and recovered five of them and even has an interception on his stellar playing resume.

Cause of death remains unknown

Haggans' cause of death has not yet been revealed, per Colin Dunlap of 93.7 The Fan.

He is survived by his son Damon and a daughter, Alianna, per WPXI.

Tributes continue to flood social media

NFL fans paid tribute to Clark on social media after his death was announced on Tuesday.

One wrote: "Clark was loved. He will be missed dearly by all of us that knew him. Most of all he loved his kids beyond measure. RIP Clark."

Another said: "Thanks for the memories Clark."

And a third added: "My all-time favorite football Ram. This play below was the first game of my freshman year at CSU at the old Mile High Stadium. I’ll never forget this play. Thanks for the memories!"

NFL teams Haggans played for

Clark Haggans played for a plethora of NFL teams during his 13-year career including:

Pittsburgh Steelers

Arizona Cardinals

San Francisco 49ers

Haggans was a Super Bowl champion

Haggans spent seven seasons with the Steelers, famously sacking Seattle’s Matt Hasselbeck on the opening drive of the 2005 Super Bowl on the way to victory.

During his stellar Steelers career, Haggans recorded 332 tackles, 12 forced fumbles, and 32.5 sacks.

It has been reported that Haggans died suddenly at age 46 as the cause of death has not yet been revealed, per Colin Dunlap of 93.7 The Fan.
